Component.name: Artillery_Gun
Component.Description: 1) Refers to any engine used for the discharge of large projectiles and served by a crew of men. 2) Cannon-like weapons operated by more than one person.

Component.name: Barrel
Component.Description: The barrel of a gun or cannon; used to control the elevation angle of the weapon.

Component.name: Cannon
Component.Description: 1) A cannon is any large tubular firearm designed to fire a heavy projectile over a long distance. 2) Main gun on a helicopter or on an aircraft. 3) Rifled gun with a caliber of 20 mm or more. 4) Ship defense artillery cannons, 5 inches or higher.

Component.name: Chaff_Dispenser
Component.Description: Identifies the device that dispenses chaff, a countermeasure against radar-guided missiles.

Component.name: Flare_Dispenser
Component.Description: Identifies the device that dispenses flares, a countermeasure against infrared homing missiles.

Component.name: Gun
Component.Description: Cannon of smaller caliber.

Component.name: Muzzle
Component.Description: The end of the barrel from which the projectile will exit.

Component.name: Pylon
Component.Description: A finlike device used to attach auxiliary equipment to an aircraft.

Component.name: Rack
Component.Description: A framework set up on a vehicle to carry loads, as in a missile rack, a bomb rack, etc.

Component.name: Rail
Component.Description: Wingtip Missile rail

Component.name: Rocket_Launcher
Component.Description: A structural device designed to support and hold a rocket in position for firing.

Component.name: Turret
Component.Description: Refers to a rotating weapon or sensor platform. It controls the azimuth of a gun, cannon, radar dish, antenna, etc.

Component.name: Blade
Component.Description: Rotor or propeller blade

Component.name: Cabin
Component.Description: The passenger area of an airplane.

Component.name: Cargo
Component.Description: Compartment on the airplane for carrying payloads

Component.name: Cockpit
Component.Description: 1) A usually enclosed space in the forward fuselage of an airplane containing the flying controls, instrument panel, and seats for the pilot and copilot or crew. 2) Protective cover made of glass (or Plexiglas) that protects the pilot from the elements.

Component.name: Fuselage
Component.Description: Aircraft main body holding crew and passengers or cargo.

Component.name: Landing_Light
Component.Description: A light of very high intensity used on aircraft to illuminate the terrain and runway ahead during nighttime takeoff and landing procedures.

Component.name: Propeller
Component.Description: A mechanical device, with shaped blades that turn on a shaft, to push against air or water, especially one used for propelling an aircraft or boat.

Component.name: Rotor
Component.Description: 1) A rotating part of a mechanical device. 2) A system of rotating airfoils, as the ones of a helicopter.

Component.name: Wing
Component.Description: A wing surface used to produce lift and therefore flight, for travel in the air or another gaseous medium. The wing shape is usually an airfoil.

Component.name: Aileron
Component.Description: Control surfaces hinged at the back of the wings which by deflecting up or down help to bank the airplane.

Component.name: Canard
Component.Description: Small horizontal stabilizers usually at front of the aircraft, common on delta wing aircraft that controls pitch.

Component.name: Elevator
Component.Description: Control surfaces usually found at the back of the aircraft's tail section to control the pitch of the aircraft. Also called horizontal stabilizers.

Component.name: Flap
Component.Description: Hinged control surface located at the trailing edge of the wing inboard of the ailerons

Component.name: Leading_Edge
Component.Description: Leading edge control surfaces (also called Slats) move out from the front of the wings to make the wing space larger. This helps to increase the lifting force of the wing at slower speeds like takeoff and landing.

Component.name: Rudder
Component.Description: 1) A movable control surface attached to a vertical stabilizer, located at the rear of an airplane and used, along with the ailerons, to turn the airplane. 2) A vertical blade at the stern of a vessel that can be turned to change the vessel's direction when in motion.

Component.name: Speed_Brake
Component.Description: A controllable surface that is extended in flight to create extra drag and greatly decrease speed

Component.name: Spoiler
Component.Description: An aerodynamic device that changes the direction of airflow in order to reduce lift or aerodynamic drag and/or improve engine cooling.

Component.name: Stabilizer
Component.Description: The horizontal stabilizer is a fixed or adjustable surface from which an elevator may be hinged. A vertical stabilizer (also called a fin) is fixed to the aircraft’s tail and supports the rudder.

Component.name: Trim_Tab
Component.Description: A small, auxiliary control surface in the trailing edge of a wingform, adjustable mechanically or by hand, to counteract aerodynamic forces on the main control surfaces.

Component.name: Engine
Component.Description: Designates the motor engine or propulsion system.

Component.name: Nacelle
Component.Description: Engine nacelle compartment mount which holds the engine

Component.name: Thrust_Reverser
Component.Description: Thrust reversers are used to slow jet aircraft following touchdown, in form of a blast shield that covers the nozzles and deflects the exhaust.

Component.name: Thrust_Vector_Nozzle
Component.Description: Movable exhaust nozzle, found on next generation aircraft to increase the maneuverability by controlling the direction of the thrust

Component.name: Exhaust_System
Component.Description: An exhaust system conveys burnt gases from an internal combustion engine.

Component.name: Fuel_Tank
Component.Description: External fuel tank

Component.name: Axle
Component.Description: The pin or spindle on which a wheel revolves, or which revolves with a wheel.

Component.name: Bogey
Component.Description: A bogey is a structural device that attaches multiple wheels on the same gear unit

Component.name: Landing_Gear
Component.Description: Aircraft landing gear parts

Component.name: Louver
Component.Description: Gear louver doors

Component.name: Strut
Component.Description: The landing strut is the "leg" of the gear unit that attaches the bogey/wheels

Component.name: Wheel
Component.Description: Wheels that are attached to the bogey

Component.name: Boom
Component.Description: A long, rigid, hollow shaft around a telescopic fuel tube usually fitted to the rear of the tanker.

Component.name: Drogue
Component.Description: Sometime called a basket. A funnel-shaped device attached at the end of a hose on a tanker aircraft for connecting with the probe on the aircraft to be refueled in flight.

Component.name: Hose
Component.Description: A flexible tube for conveying fuel.

Component.name: Nozzle
Component.Description: Mounted at the end of the fuel tube, the nozzle mates with the receptacle on the receiver aircraft.

Component.name: Probe
Component.Description: A rigid, but sometime jointed and retractable, arm placed on the side of the nose of the aircraft to be refueled in flight.

Component.name: Receptacle
Component.Description: A contact device installed on top and along the centerline of the aircraft to be refueled. The boom connects to the receptacle.

Component.name: Ruddevator
Component.Description: Small wings mounted at the end of the boom. Allows the operator to fly the boom in position and align the nozzle with the receptacle.

Component.name: Tube
Component.Description: Telescopic fuel tube housed within the boom.

Component.name: Anchor
Component.Description: A heavy device dropped by a chain, cable, or rope to the bottom of a body of water for restraining the motion of a vessel or other floating object.

Component.name: Antenna
Component.Description: A device to receive or transmit radio signals by converting electromagnetic radiation into electrical signals.

Component.name: Bow
Component.Description: The forward end of a vessel or surface ship.

Component.name: Bridge
Component.Description: Command post on a ship

Component.name: Conning_Tower
Component.Description: The low observation tower of a submarine, constituting the main entrance to the interior.

Component.name: Deck
Component.Description: The floor-like covering of the horizontal sections, or compartments, of a ship. Small vessels have only one deck; larger ships have two or three decks.

Component.name: Flight_Deck
Component.Description: The flight deck of an aircraft carrier is the surface from which its aircraft take off and land, essentially a miniature airfield at sea.

Component.name: Mast
Component.Description: 1) A tall, slim structure used to support, for example, the sails on a ship, floodlights or an aerial. 2) Radio masts and towers are, typically, tall structures designed to support antennas (also known as aerials in the UK) for telecommunications and broadcasting, including television.

Component.name: Stern
Component.Description: The rear part or after end of a ship or vessel.

Component.name: Runway
Component.Description: A cleared strip on which planes land and take off.

Component.name: Chimney
Component.Description: A chimney is a system for venting hot flue gases or smoke from a boiler, stove, furnace or fireplace to the outside atmosphere.

Component.name: Floor
Component.Description: 1) The bottom or lower part of any room; the supporting surface of a room. 2) A structure formed of beams, girders, etc, with proper covering, which divides a building horizontally into stories.

Component.name: Hall
Component.Description: A hall is fundamentally, a relatively large space enclosed by a roof and walls. The hall of a house is the space inside the front door from which the rooms are reached.

Component.name: Roof
Component.Description: The cover at the top of a building

Component.name: Room
Component.Description: A portion of space within a building that is enclosed or partitioned off from other parts.

Component.name: Wall
Component.Description: A wall is a usually solid structure that defines and sometimes protects an area. Most commonly, a wall separates space in buildings into rooms, or protects or delineates a space in the open air. There are three principal types of structural walls: building walls, exterior boundary walls, and retaining walls.

Component.name: Window
Component.Description: A window is an opening in an otherwise solid and opaque surface through which light and, sometimes, air can pass. It is usually glass or a strong, transparent plastic. For example, a window can be in the wall of a house.

Component.name: Caterpillar_Tread
Component.Description: Large (modular) tracks used on tanks, construction equipment and certain other off-road vehicles. Made of a number of rigid units that are joined to each other. The tracks help the vehicle to distribute its weight more evenly over a large surface area.

Component.name: Hatch
Component.Description: 1) A horizontal door in a floor or ceiling. 2) A passageway between the decks of a ship. 3) A small doorway, especially in an aircraft or spacecraft.

Component.name: Hitch
Component.Description: 1) Hitch knot, a knot used to attach a rope to a fixed object. 2) Tow hitch, a construction on a truck or car to attach a trailer.

Component.name: Trunk
Component.Description: The luggage storage compartment of a sedan style car.

Component.name: Door
Component.Description: All kinds of doors: main entrance doors on buildings, back doors, cargo doors, passenger doors, cockpit doors, weapon bay doors, gear louver doors, emergency exit doors, car driver’s and passengers doors, etc.

Component.name: Helipad
Component.Description: A takeoff and landing area for helicopters. Provides a clearly marked hard surface away from obstacles where a helicopter can land. Helipads are usually constructed out of concrete and are marked with a circle and/or a letter "H", so as to be visible from the air. Helipads are found on the roof of hospitals, corporate head offices, and on large ships.

Component.name: Hull
Component.Description: 1) The main structural body of the boat, not including the deck, keel, mast, or cabin. 2) The main body of an armored tank.

Component.name: Porthole
Component.Description: A porthole is a small, generally circular, window used on the hull of ships, armored vehicles, aircraft, automobiles, and even spacecraft.

Component.name: Searchlight
Component.Description: A light source that projects a bright beam of light; usually mounted on a device so that it can be swiveled about.

Component.name: Tire
Component.Description: A tire covers the circumference of a wheel to increase the adherence of the wheel to the rolling surface. The tire also plays the role of a shock absorber to dampen the oscillations caused by irregularities on the surface.

Component.name: Windshield
Component.Description: A transparent screen located in front of the occupants of a vehicle to protect them from the wind and weather.
